definitions.definition: To place confidence in, to rely on, to confide in.
examples: We cannot trust anyone who deceives us.

definitions.definition: To have faith in; to rely on for continuing support or aid.
To give credence to; to believe; to credit.
To hope confidently; to believe (usually with a phrase or infinitive clause as the object)
examples: I trust you have cleaned your room?

definitions.definition: to show confidence in a person by entrusting them with something.
To commit, as to one's care; to entrust.
To give credit to; to sell to upon credit, or in confidence of future payment.
examples: Merchants and manufacturers trust their customers annually with goods.

definitions.definition: To rely on (something), as though having trust (on it).
examples: Having lost the book, he had to trust to his memory for further details.

definitions.definition: To have trust; to be credulous; to be won to confidence; to confide.
To sell or deliver anything in reliance upon a promise of payment; to give credit.

main_definition: ( transitive ) To place confidence in, to rely on, to confide in.
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive , with in ) To have faith in; to rely on for continuing support or aid.
( transitive ) To give credence to; to believe; to credit.
( transitive ) To hope confidently; to believe (usually with a phrase or infinitive clause as the object)
( transitive ) to show confidence in a person by entrusting them with something.
( transitive ) To commit, as to one's care; to entrust.
( transitive ) To give credit to; to sell to upon credit, or in confidence of future payment.
( intransitive , followed by to ) To rely on (something), as though having trust (on it).
( archaic , transitive ) To risk; to venture confidently.
( intransitive ) To have trust; to be credulous; to be won to confidence; to confide.
( archaic , intransitive ) To sell or deliver anything in reliance upon a promise of payment; to give credit.
